articles.headline: Obama Could Replace Aides Bruised by a Cascade of Crises
articles.snippet: Stumbles in the handling of the Ebola crisis and the Islamic State have fueled speculation that President Obama may shake up his foreign policy team.
articles.abstract: Stumbles in the handling of the Ebola crisis and the Islamic State have fueled speculation that President Obama may shake up his foreign policy team.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One day this month, as the nation shuddered with fears of an Ebola outbreak and American warplanes pounded Sunni militants in Syria, President Obama’s national security adviser, Susan E. Rice, invited a group of foreign policy experts to the White House to hear their views of how the administration was performing.

articles.headline: Federal Reserve Caps Its Bond Purchases; Focus Turns to Interest Rates
articles.snippet: Many see the end of quantitative easing as a milestone in America’s slow recovery, and the central bank says the likelihood of persistently low inflation has diminished.
articles.abstract: Many see the end of quantitative easing as a milestone in America’s slow recovery, and the central bank says the likelihood of persistently low inflation has diminished.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a series of sweeping campaigns to revive the American economy, the Federal Reserve has spent much of the last six years purchasing trillions of dollars of bonds. Now it is done.

articles.headline: Banker in Middle of Fight Between Goldman Sachs and Libya
articles.snippet: The emergence of Jaber George Jabbour in a battle between Libya’s sovereign wealth fund and Goldman Sachs reveals the complex relationship between banks and public sector entities.
articles.abstract: The emergence of Jaber George Jabbour in a battle between Libya’s sovereign wealth fund and Goldman Sachs reveals the complex relationship between banks and public sector entities.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — As an analyst at Goldman Sachs, Jaber George Jabbour learned the intricacies of sophisticated financial products by helping to create derivatives bets for big investors like pension funds.

articles.headline: Prosecutors Suspect Repeat Offenses on Wall Street
articles.snippet: Prosecutors are exploring whether to strengthen deferred or nonprosecution agreements from two years ago, or scrap them altogether and force the banks to plead guilty to a crime, say lawyers briefed on the cases.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors are exploring whether to strengthen deferred or nonprosecution agreements from two years ago, or scrap them altogether and force the banks to plead guilty to a crime, say lawyers briefed on the cases.
articles.lead_paragraph: It would be the Wall Street equivalent of a parole violation: Just two years after avoiding prosecution for a variety of crimes, some of the world’s biggest banks are suspected of having broken their promises to behave.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: $1.5 Million Sent in Error to Money Manager (Both Are Missing)
articles.snippet: Credit Suisse is trying to find Joseph Galbraith, manager of Galbraith Capital Investment Management, to which the bank says it sent the money in January.
articles.abstract: Credit Suisse is trying to find Joseph Galbraith, manager of Galbraith Capital Investment Management, to which the bank says it sent the money in January.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the board game Monopoly, when the bank makes an error in your favor, the player gets to keep the money. A hedge fund manager is acting as if he has drawn that lucky card for real, a lawsuit against him contends.

articles.headline: Louisiana’s Rogues Yield to National Issues
articles.snippet: Voters are finding it hard to get excited about broad-scope campaigns that have left the local politicking of the past as mostly a fading memory.
articles.abstract: Voters are finding it hard to get excited about broad-scope campaigns that have left the local politicking of the past as mostly a fading memory.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ROADS, La. — A politician at a street fair is usually an inconvenience, an ordeal to be endured as he thrusts a flier at your chest and a smile at your face. But the silver-haired candidate pushing his 1-year-old in a stroller through the funnel-cake stands and craft booths at the harvest festival here did not have to try so hard. The glad-handers rushed up to him.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Peter Chernin: A Solo Success in Hollywood, Where Many Fizzle
articles.snippet: While many former studio heads fail when striking out on their own, Mr. Chernin has found success as an independent producer, with seven hits in a row.
articles.abstract: While many former studio heads fail when striking out on their own, Mr. Chernin has found success as an independent producer, with seven hits in a row.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — When Peter Chernin stepped down as Rupert Murdoch’s second in command in 2009 and became an independent movie and television producer, the likeliest outcome was a long, painful fizzle.

articles.headline: In Democratic Election Ads in South, a Focus on Racial Scars
articles.snippet: Democrats in the closest Senate races in the South are turning to racially charged messages to jolt African-Americans into voting and stop a Republican takeover in Washington.
articles.abstract: Democrats in the closest Senate races in the South are turning to racially charged messages to jolt African-Americans into voting and stop a Republican takeover in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the final days before the election, Democrats in the closest Senate races across the South are turning to racially charged messages — invoking Trayvon Martin’s death, the unrest in Ferguson, Mo., and Jim Crow-era segregation — to jolt African-Americans into voting and stop a Republican takeover in Washington.

articles.headline: Israel to Reopen Contested Holy Site in Jerusalem
articles.snippet: After closing it over security concerns, Israel said the site, which Jews call the Temple Mount and Muslims the Noble Sanctuary, would reopen on Friday.
articles.abstract: After closing it over security concerns, Israel said the site, which Jews call the Temple Mount and Muslims the Noble Sanctuary, would reopen on Friday.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel barred all access to a contested sacred site in the Old City for the first time in many years on Thursday, a step that a Palestinian spokesman denounced as “a declaration of war” and one that strained Israel’s crucial alliance with neighboring Jordan.
articles.byline: By Jodi Rudoren and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: Third-Quarter G.D.P. Rose 3.5%, Lifting Hopes for U.S. Economy
articles.snippet: The higher-than-expected bump in gross domestic product was driven in part by a spurt in federal spending, largely in defense, and private investment.
articles.abstract: The higher-than-expected bump in gross domestic product was driven in part by a spurt in federal spending, largely in defense, and private investment.
articles.lead_paragraph: Unlike the seventh game of the World Series, the debate over the economy’s strength sometimes seems like a playoff competition that goes on forever between skeptics and believers. But on Thursday, the boosters won at least a temporary victory with a government report that estimated the nation’s economic output rose at a healthy 3.5 percent annual rate in the third quarter.

articles.headline: Apple’s Tim Cook Says That He Is ‘Proud to Be Gay’
articles.snippet: Mr. Cook, Apple’s chief executive, is by far the most prominent executive of a public company to openly declare his homosexuality.
articles.abstract: Mr. Cook, Apple’s chief executive, is by far the most prominent executive of a public company to openly declare his homosexuality.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Timothy D. Cook, Apple’s chief executive, likes to tell people that his predecessor, Steven P. Jobs, urged him to be himself when he took over the company.
articles.byline: By Brian X. Chen and Vindu Goel

articles.headline: Radio Dusts Off Mistletoe, in October
articles.snippet: With one station switching in mid-October, and 500 doing so by December, the all-Christmas format is one of radio’s most enduring and profitable gimmicks.
articles.abstract: With one station switching in mid-October, and 500 doing so by December, the all-Christmas format is one of radio’s most enduring and profitable gimmicks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. — It was still two weeks before Halloween when WEZW-FM, the easy-listening standby of Cape May County, pushed the Christmas button.
